section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Peter H. Reynolds
section-block.rac_book_summary: Ramon’s art makes his brother laugh, so Ramon thinks he’s not good enough. Then his little sister shows him a different way to think about art.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to share what they like to draw. Do they like to draw animals or people, buildings or monsters? Encourage children to listen to each other.
Invite children to move and sing “Skip to my Lou,” taking turns to change actions: twist, jump, hop, stretch, wiggle, and so on. Point out that dancing is also a form of art.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we will read Ish by Peter H. Reynolds.
This is a narrative about a boy who likes to draw. Scout likes books like this one, because he loves stories about people creating things.
I need you to look at me and listen carefully as I read. While we read, let’s think about this guiding question.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Marisol feel about Ramon’s art?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer the questions. Remind children to speak clearly so that others can understand them.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can you tell that Ramon really loves to draw?
What does Leon think of Ramon’s drawing of a vase?
How do you think Ramon feels about drawing now? How can you tell? Have you ever felt like that?
Ramon stared at Marisol’s roomful of his drawings. How is staring different from just looking?
Why do you think Marisol put Ramon’s art up in her room?
How does Ramon feel about his drawings after talking to Marisol? Have you ever felt like that?
What does Ramon do after Marisol helps him see his drawings in a new way? How do you think he feels about his drawings now?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does Marisol feel about Ramon’s art?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to select a few children to share ideas.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Marisol thinks Ramon’s drawings are good enough to hang up.
Marisol thinks Ramon’s art is worth saving.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read short sentences about various ways of making art.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why would you want to hang someone else’s drawing on your wall?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Attention problems affect as many as 40 percent of preK children. As you read aloud, minimize distractions by reducing background noise and having children focus on your face as well as on the pages of the book you are reading. Develop consistent routines that grab children’s attention and help them to focus on the task at hand.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Show Pride
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss times when children have felt proud of their accomplishments. Perhaps they learned to skate, tie their shoes, or count to 20. How did they show their pride? Distinguish between showing pride and bragging by explaining that showing pride is building yourself up, whereas bragging makes someone else feel put down. (MB)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read Ish, let’s see how Ramon learns about the Mind Builder show pride.
Clifford is proud of himself for listening carefully to the story! Can you listen as well as Clifford does?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages in the story to watch Ramon learn to show pride.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: First, Ramon felt proud of his art. Then Leon burst out laughing. How does this change Ramon’s feelings about his art?
Leon’s laughter bothers Ramon. Why does Ramon’s pride depend on what his family thinks? Do you feel that way, too? (MB)
How does a different member of Ramon’s family help him get his pride back? How could you help a friend feel proud of his or her work? (MB)
How can you tell that Ramon feels pride in his drawings again? (MB)
How does having pride in his drawing and writing help Ramon? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give each child a small piece of modeling clay and encourage children to spend five minutes making something. Then let children present their creations and tell how their work makes them feel. Model showing appreciation for others’ artwork by praising the work of each child. Then, invite other children in the group to offer words of praise for each artist. If you wish, provide them with a sentence frame: “I like your art because ___ .”
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how creating and appreciating art makes them feel.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children at this age are just beginning to be able to recognize pride in themselves. You can stimulate this emotion by pointing it out: “You did a great job! You must feel very happy and proud of yourself.” It is equally important to model pride; for example, by saying, “I am proud of the job we did cleaning up today!” (Terebush, 2017)

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that as they listen to a story, they can make connections between the story and their own lives.
Have children crouch. Tell them to jump up when they hear a word that ends the same way as Ish. Say a series of one-syllable words that includes dish, wish, and fish.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We are going to reread Ish by Peter H. Reynolds.
Scout likes this story because even though it is a made-up story, it reminds him of his own life.
Think about this guiding question as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What lesson does Ramon learn about making art?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to respond. Encourage them to speak loudly and clearly and to use full sentences. If necessary, ask them to add to their answers.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: At the beginning, how does Ramon feel about making art?
How does Ramon feel about making art after his brother laughs at him? Do you understand his feelings? Why?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Make a Connection hand signal.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Ramon feel about his art after Marisol shows him her room?
When Ramon draws “loose lines... without worry,” how is he feeling?
Which words here end the same way as vase-ish?
How does Ramon feel about making “ish” art? Do you understand his feelings? Why?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Make a Connection hand signal

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: If you listened carefully and shared your ideas thoughtfully, you should easily be able to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What lesson does Ramon learn about making art?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Ramon learns that art does not need to be perfect.
Ramon learns that making art should be fun.
Ramon learns to be proud of making art his own way.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you write together about feeling good about being creative. Invite children to share their own experiences.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Ramon learn that making art should be fun or worrying?
Ramon learns that making art should be f___ (fun).
Ramon learns that making art should be fun.
If you drew art that was “ish,” how would you feel about it?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: By age 4, children should be able to speak in understandable sentences. For children who lack articulation orwho mumble, try repeating clearly and crisply what they say, so that they hear how their words should sound. If children continue to respond in one- or two-word phrases, encourage them to add on, and model how to do so.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children use the Make a Connection hand signal to indicate that they want to respond to these questions: What have we learned about making art so far this week? What does Ramon’s story tell you about being proud of the art you make? How do you show that you are proud of your own art?
Introduce two words that connect to the Big Chart.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In this informational text, A Horse, of Course, we are going to read about different kinds of art that people make.
Scout loves to listen and talk about different kinds of art.
Both Ish and A Horse, of Course tell about art and people who make art. Let’s see how the two readings are alike and different.
As we read A Horse, of Course, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s essential question:
How can we express ourselves by making art?

section.rac_body-text: Read one section at a time to have children listen for specifics. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Listen as I read. Who drew these horse pictures? Use a sentence to tell us.
Listen as I read. What was used to sculpt this horse? Use a sentence to tell us.
Listen as I read. Where is this horse? Use a sentence to tell us.
Listen as I read. What did the artist use to mold this horse? Use a sentence to tell us.

section.rac_body-text: Give children drawing materials such as colored pencils, crayons, and drawing paper. Challenge them to make their own image of a horse, using the art on the flip chart as a guide. Remind them that it’s fine if their horse is just “horse-ish”! Provide time for children to present their art, using full sentences and speaking clearly. Remind them to show their appreciation for each other’s work.
Provide a writing prompt about making art and offer feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As they try to compose sentences to respond to questions about the reading, some bilingual children may mix words from their two languages. This kind of code mixing is natural and not problematic. To guide children, you may wish to provide sentence frames such as: “_____ drew these pictures” and “This horse is made of _____.”

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite each child to show and tell about a favorite piece of art they have made in class. Encourage viewers to compliment each artist’s work.
Have children sing the first verse of this song with “a green and yellow basket,” then have volunteers name new color pairs (red, orange; blue, purple) to sing as they repeat.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will retell and reenact the book Ish by Peter H. Reynolds.
Scout likes made-up stories about people who seem real. Scout likes to connect books to his own life!
We have read about Ramon and his “ish” art. As we look at his story once more, please think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Does art have to be perfect? Why or why not?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to select children to answer the questions below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does Ramon feel about his drawing as the book begins? Show how he feels.
How do Ramon’s feelings change after Leon laughs at his art? How do you know? Show how he feels.
When he sees Marisol’s gallery, how does Ramon feel? Show how he feels.
Once Ramon looks at his art through Marisol’s eyes, how does he feel about it? Show how he feels.
How does Ramon’s art-making change when his feelings change? Does Ramon believe that his art needs to be perfect? How do you know?

section.rac_body-text: Have children use Turn and Talk to discuss the guiding question. Remind them to speak clearly and to respond in full sentences.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Does art have to be perfect? Why or why not?
section.rac_body-text: After a moment or two, use Equity Sticks to select 2–3 children to share their ideas:
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Art does not need to be perfect. It is more important to enjoy making art.
Art should be as perfect as you can make it so that people see your work at its best.
As long as you enjoy it, art does not have to be perfect.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about turning ideas from their imaginations into pictures. Then have them share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does art have to be perfect to be good?
Art does n___ (not) have to be perfect to be good.
Art does not have to be perfect to be good.
What do you feel best about when you make your own art?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children with perfectionist tendencies may rip up papers, become weepy, and criticize others. Learning to set realistic standards is a difficult lesson for young children. Try to make your classroom a calm and safe place where failure is an expected part of growth and learning is process-oriented rather than outcome-oriented.
